Review Bimetallic oxide catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol: Recent advances and challenges Jian-Feng Wu a b 1 * Li-Ye Liang a b 1 Zheng Che b 1 Yu-Ting Miao b Lingjun Chou a * a State Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Catalysis and Carbon Dioxide Utilization, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Lanzhou 730000, Gansu, China State Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Catalysis and Carbon Dioxide Utilization Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics Chinese Academy of Sciences Lanzhou Gansu 730000 China State Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Catalysis and Carbon Dioxide Utilization, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences, Lanzhou 730000, Gansu, China b State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry, Key Laboratory of Nonferrous Metals Chemistry and Resources Utilization of Gansu Province, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lanzhou University, Lanzhou 730000, Gansu, China State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry Key Laboratory of Nonferrous Metals Chemistry and Resources Utilization of Gansu Province College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering Lanzhou University Lanzhou Gansu 730000 China State Key Laboratory of Applied Organic Chemistry, Key Laboratory of Nonferrous Metals Chemistry and Resources Utilization of Gansu Province, College of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lanzhou University, Lanzhou 730000, Gansu, China * Corresponding author. 1 Contributed equally to this work. Against the backdrop of global energy and environmental crises, the technology of CO2 hydrogenation to produce methanol is garnering widespread attention as an innovative carbon capture and utilization solution. Bimetallic oxide catalysts have emerged as the most promising research subject in the field due to their exceptional catalytic performance and stability. The performance of bimetallic oxide catalysts is influenced by multiple factors, including the selection of carrier materials, the addition of promoters, and the synthesis process. Different types of bimetallic oxide catalysts exhibit significant differences in microstructure, surface active sites, and electronic structure, which directly determine the yield and selectivity of methanol. Although bimetallic oxide catalysts offer significant advantages over traditional copper-based catalysts, they still encounter challenges related to activity and cost. In order to enhance catalyst performance, future investigations must delve into microstructure control, surface modification, and reaction kinetics. Graphical Abstract Bimetallic oxides for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol were reviewed, covering In-based oxides, MaZrO x catalysts, and Co-based oxides, discussing synthesis methods, synergistic effects, active sites, reaction pathways, kinetics processes, crystal phases, and additives. Keywords CO2 hydrogenation Methanol Bimetallic oxide catalyst Catalytic performance Reaction mechanism 1 Introduction With the gradual depletion of fossil fuels and the consequential release of copious amounts of CO2, energy and environmental issues have become increasingly prominent, posing a grave threat to the survival of humanity [1–3]. The current focus of research is on reducing CO2 emissions through the process of carbon capture and utilization (CCU). By utilizing CO2 as a non-conventional and sustainable carbon source for chemical production, the reliance on fossil fuels such as petroleum can be diminished, and the issue of carbon emissions can be suitably addressed. The utilization of CO2 as a chemical feedstock is constrained by its thermodynamic stability and kinetic inertness, with a standard Gibbs free energy of formation of −394.4 kJ mol–1 [4]. The application of CO2 as a sole reactant necessitates a high energy input. However, when a co-reactant with a higher Gibbs free energy, such as H2, is introduced, the reaction becomes thermodynamically more favorable. The catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 utilizing green hydrogen for producing valuable commodities like methanol and ethanol, as well as short- and long-chain hydrocarbons, is presently a focal point in academic and industrial research [5–8]. Among the numerous hydrogenation products, methanol is a particularly favored option. Methanol possesses versatility as a chemical, displaying utility as both a liquid fuel and a precursor to produce valuable chemicals such as formaldehyde, olefins, dimethyl ether (DME), and acetic acid [5]. The notion of a “methanol economy” was introduced by Olah et al. [9], who proposed that CO2 hydrogenation represents a highly viable method (Fig. 1 ). CO2 hydrogenation is one of the most promising renewable pathways for generating methanol. In a similar vein, Shih et al. [10] coined the term “liquid sunshine”. They suggested that this type of methanol will be an indispensable component of a carbon circular economy and a crucial energy source in the future. The primary approach for methanol production is anticipated to be the CO2 hydrogenation process, which involves utilizing renewable energy to generate H2 via water electrolysis. This is presently a key area of research in both academic and industrial circles. The conventional method of manufacturing methanol involves the use of copper-based catalysts (Cu/ZnO/Al2O3) under extreme conditions (493–573 K, P = 5–10 MPa) to convert 3% of CO2-containing syngas into methanol [3]. Additionally, industrial production of methanol from CO2 hydrogenation has been accomplished using similar copper-based catalysts and reaction conditions [11]. This industrial process involves three main reactions: methanol synthesis from CO2 (MS), CO hydrogenation (COH), and reverse water-gas-shift reaction (RWGS). MS CO2 + 3H2 = CH3OH + H2O ΔH 298 K = −49.5 kJ mol−1 COH CO + 2H2 = CH3OH ΔH 298 K = −90.6 kJ mol−1 RWGS CO2 + H2 = CO + H2O ΔH 298 K = 41.2 kJ mol−1 The MS and COH reactions exhibit exothermic behavior with a reduction in the quantity of gas molecules, while the RWGS reaction displays endothermic behavior with a consistent number of gas molecules. Hence, from a thermodynamic standpoint, the production of methanol is more favorable under conditions of low temperature and high pressure. In practical manufacturing, the elevation of reaction temperature is essential to enhance kinetic efficiency, which unavoidably results in a heightened occurrence of the RWGS reaction. Therefore, the identification of a catalyst capable of effectively activating CO2 at a suitable temperature, while only breaking a singular C=O bond, is highly desirable. Cu-based catalysts are commonly utilized in methanol production due to their enhanced efficiency towards both MS and RWGS. However, as a byproduct of the reaction, water is generated, which can lead to the sintering of the active phase of the catalyst, ultimately resulting in instability [12,13]. Consequently, scientists have upgraded the existing copper-based catalysts [14–17] and developed a series of advanced catalysts, such as noble metal-based catalysts [18–22], non-noble metal catalysts (including alloy catalysts [23], intermetallic compound catalysts [24,25], bimetallic oxide catalysts, MOF/ZIF-derived catalysts [26–28], and other specific structure catalysts [29]). Bimetallic oxide catalysts have emerged as a prominent research area due to their exceptional catalytic efficiency, remarkable durability, and applicability to large-scale industrial production. The present review centers on the utilization of bimetallic oxide catalysts for the purpose of CO2 hydrogenation into methanol, delving into the techniques employed for their preparation, the active sites or structures of the catalysts, the reaction mechanisms, as well as the reaction kinetics. In this comprehensive review, we have strived to encompass the important developments in bimetallic oxide catalysts between 2015 and 2024, albeit there may be some omissions. Furthermore, the coupling of bimetallic oxide catalysts and zeolites has been successfully achieved for the production of a series of C2+ hydrocarbons through the hydrogenation of CO2, as the reaction temperatures for methanol synthesis using bimetallic oxide and methanol conversion using zeolites fall within the same temperature range. However, due to space constraints, this review will not delve into this aspect. Interested readers are encouraged to consult recent review papers [30,31] for information on advancements in this area. 2 Classification of bimetallic oxide catalysts The combination of two elements present in bimetallic oxides results in a significant synergistic effect, leading to a substantial increase in the production of methanol. Presently, research on bimetallic oxide catalysts for the conversion of CO2 into methanol can be categorized into various types [2,3,32]. These include Co-based oxide catalysts, In-based oxide catalysts, MaZrO x (M = Zn, Cd, Ce, Ga, etc.) solid-solution catalysts, and other catalysts, such as spinel-type [33–35]. The selected catalysts’ preparation methods and catalytic performance are enumerated in T@able 1 . Based on the observations of T@able 1, the following conclusions can be made. (1) The selectivity of methanol proceeds as follows: In2O3/ZrO2 (77.3%–99.8%) > MaZrO x (M = Zn, Cd, Ga, etc.) solid-solution catalysts (70%–95.6%) > Co-based oxide catalysts (30%). (2) The method used to synthesize catalysts using identical elements greatly impacts the catalyst’s selectivity, as demonstrated by the comparison between refluxing in ammonia (95.6%) and impregnation (75.1%). (3) The space time yield (STY) of methanol and DME ranks as: GaZrO x (760 gMeOH kgcat −1 h−1) > ZnO-ZrO2 (350–737 gMeOH kgcat −1 h−1) > In2O3/ZrO2 (295 gMeOH kgcat −1 h−1) under similar reaction conditions. 2.1 Co-based oxide catalysts Co-based oxide catalysts are extensively employed in the Fischer-Tropsch synthesis owing to their exceptional reactivity and minimal selectivity towards the water-gas shift reaction, which has attracted the attention from researchers. The Somorjai group [52] has documented the remarkable activity and selectivity of a MnO x /m-Co3O4 bimetallic oxide catalyst in facilitating CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. The MnO x /m-Co3O4 catalyst consists of nano-sized manganese oxide particles supported on mesoporous spinel cobalt oxide, and its catalytic performance surpasses that of individual metal oxide, as depicted in Fig. 2 . Through the utilization of X-ray absorption spectroscopy (XAS) and electron energy loss spectroscopy (EELS), it has been demonstrated that there exists an active interface between the cobalt oxide surface and manganese oxide nanoparticles, which contains Co metal cores, and the MnO nanoparticles dispersed throughout the catalyst. The exceptional catalytic activity observed at the MnO x /CoO interface is indicative of a significant synergistic effect between the two distinct metal oxide components. The Yu group [50] conducted a study on the utilization of mesoporous manganese-cobalt spinel oxide with varying Co/Mn ratios in the process of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. They concluded that the improved selectivity towards methanol was due to the synergy effect of cobalt and manganese oxides, the augmentation of surface area caused by Mn doping, and the subsequent rise in the concentration of surface Mn species and surface alkalinity. However, the primary product of this catalyst is methane, and it might be essential to optimize the surface composition or introduce supplementary components to augment methanol selectivity. In the aforementioned examples, the introduction of Mn on the surface of cobalt oxide has been shown to regulate the selectivity of CO2 hydrogenation products, shifting the product selectivity from methane to methanol. The incorporation of Mn possibly modulated the electronic structure of Co, altered reaction pathways, modified the surface oxidation state of Co, and enhanced the ability to activate CO2 [50]. Further experimental and theoretical investigations are required to validate the hypothesis pertaining to the phenomenon. The Xiao’s group [53] disclosed their findings on the utilization of amorphous silica as a support and ligand, leading to the creation of cobalt species modified with a rich Co-O-SiO n interface. This development served to stabilize the *CH3O intermediate, thus facilitating its subsequent hydrogenation into methanol, instead of undergoing C–O dissociation, which would produce hydrocarbons. As a result, the generation of CH4 and CO was effectively suppressed. The Shrotri’s group [54] synthesized a Co- and In-doped ZrO2 catalyst (Co-In-ZrO2), which contains atomically dispersed cobalt (Co) and indium (In) species. In the CO2 hydrogenation reaction, the Co atoms are responsible for the adsorption of CO2 and formate species, while the nearby In atoms promote the hydrogenation of the adsorbed intermediates. This synergistic effect increases the methanol selectivity of the dual-atom catalyst to 86%, and the methanol productivity is doubled compared to single-atom catalysts. The study proposes a different approach to designing mixed-oxide catalysts by preferentially adsorbing substrates and intermediates, rather than promoting H2 dissociation, to mitigate the poisoning effects of the substrates and intermediates, thereby enhancing the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. The utilization of Co-based oxide catalysts for the conversion of CO2 to methanol through hydrogenation has not been extensively documented. The reason for the low selectivity of methanol production on Co-based catalysts may be attributed to the susceptibility of their surface to C–O bond cleavage [52]. This phenomenon leads to the generation of CO and hydrocarbons as the primary catalytic products [53]. Therefore, exploring appropriate components or supports to effectively regulate the synergy between them and improve the selectivity of methanol may become a future development trend for Co-based oxide catalysts. 2.2 In-based oxide catalysts The utilization of In2O3 and In-based oxide catalysts has gained momentum in the field of methanol synthesis via CO2 hydrogenation, as these catalysts have demonstrated superior efficiency in terms of methanol selectivity and durability. Theoretical and experimental studies have established that these catalysts exhibit significant promise for both academic research and industrial applications [47,48,55–59]. The employment of In2O3 in the process of catalyzing CO2 into methanol is not a coincidence. Prior to its utilization in CO2 hydrogenation, the In2O3 catalyst has demonstrated exceptional activity and selectivity in a range of CO2 conversion reactions, such as methanol steam reforming (the reverse reaction of CO2 hydrogenation) [55], electrocatalytic generation of formic acid from CO2 [60], and photocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO [61]. The potential of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol with the aid of In2O3 catalyst is suggested by the principle of microscopic reversibility. The Ge group [56] investigated the reaction mechanism of methanol production via CO2 hydrogenation on the In2O3(110) surface with surface oxygen vacancies using density functional theory (DFT) calculations. The activation and hydrogenation of CO2 were facilitated by the presence of oxygen vacancies on the In2O3(110) surface. Additionally, they found that these vacancies stabilized crucial intermediates that are involved in the production of methanol. The catalytic cycle was completed through the generation and subsequent elimination of oxygen vacancies on the surface. Based on the results obtained from DFT calculations, the Liu group [57] evaluated the catalytic performance of In2O3 and confirmed its superior catalytic activity compared to other monometallic oxides for the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol. The Pérez-Ramírez’s group [48] investigated various supports with distinct properties, including reducible, inert, acidic, and carbon-based, with the aim of optimizing the activity and stabilization of In2O3. The investigation demonstrated that only ZrO2 had the capacity to considerably enhance the CO2 hydrogenation efficiency of In2O3, resulting in the production of methanol. The optimized In2O3/ZrO2 catalyst displayed 100% methanol selectivity and a stability of 1000 h. Compared to the unloaded In2O3 catalyst, the space-time yield of methanol was considerably enhanced, as illustrated in Fig. 3 . This clearly indicates that the bimetallic oxide catalyst possesses immense potential. The Albert group [62] also reached the conclusion that among several different metal oxide supports, the In2O3/ZrO2 has the best catalytic activity. The impact of CeO2 and ZrO2 on indium oxide-based catalysts was investigated by the Salomone’s group [63]. Incorporating varying quantities of cerium or zirconium altered the structure and morphology of the catalysts, enhancing CO2 adsorption. ZrO2 was found to enhance structural stability and electronic promotion, resulting in a catalyst with increased specific activity for methanol production. Conversely, the addition of CeO2 did not exhibit a beneficial effect on catalytic activity. Dang et al. [47] have developed an h-In2O3 nanocatalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, utilizing density functional theory calculations. This innovative approach has resulted in a high CO2 conversion of 17.6% and offers a fresh perspective on the design of efficient In-based catalysts. The Hensen’s group [59] has reported that the NiO-In2O3 catalysts exhibit superior performance in CO2 hydrogenation to methanol compared to In2O3 catalysts. The distribution of the product can be efficiently modified by tuning the catalyst composition, with the maximum rate of methanol production being achieved at a Ni loading of less than 6 wt%. The authors deduced that the NiO-In2O3 catalyst exhibits a synergistic effect between Ni and In and may be a viable alternative to Pd-In2O3 catalyst. The same group [64] prepared a series of Al-loaded In2O3-Al2O3 catalysts in a single step by using flame spray pyrolysis. It was found that aluminum could be partially doped into the In2O3 lattice, which led to the formation of more oxygen vacancies involved in CO2 adsorption and methanol production, thus prominently increasing the methanol yield. The remarkable activity and selectivity of In2O3-based catalysts have aroused the interest of numerous researchers. However, the presence of by-product water causes the rapid depletion of oxygen vacancies on the catalyst and the aggregation of In due to excessive reduction [65], ultimately leading to catalyst deactivation. Furthermore, methanol on the In2O3 based catalyst surface is susceptible to decomposition. Therefore, the catalytic performance of In2O3 based catalysts can be effectively improved by enhancing the metal-metal interaction through the adjustment of catalyst components or the addition of additives. A series of metal-modified In2O3 catalysts, such as Au δ+-In2O3–x [66], Cu/In2O3 [67], Ag/In2O3 [68], and Ru/In2O3 [69], etc., have been developed for CO2 hydrogenation, further expanding the application of In-based catalyst systems in this process. As the focus of this paper is on bimetallic oxide catalysts, a comprehensive overview of the advancements in metal-modified In2O3 catalysts is beyond the scope of this discussion. Interested readers are encouraged to refer to relevant reviews [70] for further information. 2.3 MaZrOx (Ma = Zn, Cd, Ga etc.) solid-solution catalysts Due to its exceptional acid-base and redox properties, remarkable stability, and hydrophobicity, ZrO2 serves as an excellent catalyst support, which enables it to produce strong synergistic effects with various metals [2,3,71,72]. Therefore, MaZrO x (Ma = Zn, Cd, Ga, etc.) solid-solution catalysts have gained significant attention and have been extensively investigated. In 2017, Wang et al. [36] reported a ZnO-ZrO2 solid-solution catalyst, as depicted in Fig. 4 . The catalyst exhibited an amazing result with a single-pass CO2 conversion exceeding 10%, which was significantly higher than that of pure ZnO and ZrO2 by factors of 1.3 and 14, respectively. These results highlight the crucial role of synergistic effects in catalysis. Notably, this study represents the first report on MaZrO x solid-solution catalysts. Wang et al. [43] further conducted a study on the MaZrO x solid-solution catalysts, which utilized various metal oxides. The catalysts demonstrated a methanol selectivity of up to 80% under specific conditions when Ma was either Ga or Cd, with a single-pass CO2 conversion ranging from 4.3% to 12.4%. Through structural and electronic characterization, as well as density functional theory calculations, the researchers determined that the Ma and Zr components in the MaZrO x (Ma = Cd, Ga) solid-solution catalysts displayed a strong synergistic effect. This effect promoted the heterolytic activation of H2, resulting in high activity and high methanol selectivity. This finding has significant implications for the development of more efficient catalysts for methanol production. It should be noted that despite Ga and In being in the same family of elements, Ga2O3 has not been studied as extensively as In2O3 because it was previously shown to be inactive for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, as evidenced by both theoretical calculations and experiments [57,73,74]. Through the utilization of the solvent evaporation-induced self-assembly (EISA) technique, the Wu’s group [44] successfully synthesized GaZrO x catalysts that displayed exceptional catalytic activity in the CO2 hydrogenation process, leading to the production of methanol and DME. The catalysts’ outstanding performance can be attributed to the effective dispersion of the metals and the strong synergistic interactions between Ga and Zr. In addition, a general approach for the development of bimetallic oxide catalysts has been suggested, wherein one of the catalyst components must possess the ability to activate hydrogen, such as ZnO, Ga2O3, and In2O3, while the other component must consist of variable valence metal oxides, such as Zr3+/Zr4+, Cr3+/Cr4+, Ce3+/Ce4+. To confirm the effectiveness of this approach, GaCrO x catalyst was synthesized and evaluated [44]. 3 Factors influencing the catalytic performance of bimetallic oxide catalysts In addition to temperature and pressure, the reaction of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol is strongly affected by the structure of the catalyst. Ongoing research is focused on examining the impact of catalyst composition, crystal phase, preparation method, and promoters of bimetallic oxide catalysts on their catalytic performance. 3.1 Effect of crystal phases and additives 3.1.1 Effect of crystal phases The efficiency of catalysts is strongly linked to their structure. Variations in the crystal structure of the carrier lead to alterations in surface properties, dispersity of the catalytic active component, and the interaction between the carrier and the catalytic active component; all of which, in turn, influence the catalytic activity. However, the impact of the catalyst crystal phase on catalytic activity remains a topic of debate. The crystal phase of In2O3 influences the catalytic performance of the In2O3 catalyst. In2O3 exists in three distinct crystal phases, namely cubic (c-In2O3), hexagonal (h-In2O3), and orthorhombic (o-In2O3). In each of these phases, the coordination numbers of In and O atoms are six and four respectively, although their atomic positions and bond lengths differ. c-In2O3 is the most thermodynamically stable of the three crystal phases, while h-In2O3 can be formed under atmospheric pressure and o-In2O3 requires high pressure for its generation. Consequently, c-In2O3 and h-In2O3 are suitable catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol [47]. By employing DFT calculations, Dang et al. [47] concluded that the surface of h-In2O3 (104) possessed the most favorable catalytic activity in terms of reactivity and selectivity, which was later confirmed in experiments. Wang et al. [75] conducted an interesting investigation to determine the influence of various crystal forms of In2O3 on RWGS. The results indicated that c-In2O3 had a higher rate of RWGS at temperatures lower than 623 K, while when the temperature exceeded 723 K, the activity of h-In2O3 progressively increased with the duration of the reaction, a consequence of the transition of h-In2O3 to the c-In2O3 crystal phase during the reaction. In-situ XRD results have shown that h-In2O3 can be reduced with H2 and then reoxidized to c-In2O3 when exposed to CO2. Within the temperature range typically used for catalytic hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol, h-In2O3 with specific exposed crystal planes is a more advantageous choice. However, to the best of our knowledge, there is no report that has been conducted to investigate the influence of In2O3 crystal structure in In2O3/ZrO2 catalysts. ZrO2 is the most widely used support for bimetallic oxide catalysts. ZrO2 has three common crystal phases: monoclinic (m-ZrO2), tetragonal (t-ZrO2), and cubic (c-ZrO2), as shown in Fig. 5 . At low temperatures, m-ZrO2 is the stable form, while t-ZrO2 is stable when temperatures exceed 1573 K. c-ZrO2, however, is only formed at temperatures higher than 2473 K, making it an impractical choice for use as a catalyst support. The transformation temperature from m-ZrO2 to t-ZrO2 is contingent upon the amount of lattice imperfections and promoters. Metastable t-ZrO2 is generally observed as a transition phase at low temperatures. Generally, m-ZrO2 has a higher concentration of Brønsted Zr–OH centers, stronger Lewis acidic Zr4+ ions, and stronger Lewis basic O2− ions than t-ZrO2 [76,77]. The role of ZrO2 with its various crystal phases in the bimetallic oxide catalyzed CO2 hydrogenation to methanol reaction is a subject of debate [77–83]. This controversy about the role of crystal phases has existed since the early study of Cu-based catalysts. The crystal structure of ZrO2 affects the performance of In2O3-based catalysts. Results from previous studies have indicated that In2O3/m-ZrO2 catalyst has a greater catalytic performance than In2O3/t-ZrO2 catalyst, yet the origin of this disparity in activity is still unclear. The Pérez-Ramírez’s group found that both t-ZrO2 and m-ZrO2 enable In2O3 epitaxial growth, however, the In2O3/m-ZrO2 catalyst has a greater lattice mismatch, which produces a stronger tensile force on the catalyst surface and more active sites, resulting in higher catalytic activity [80]. The Gong’s group [81] found that m-ZrO2 promotes the high dispersion of In-O-In species and enhances electron transfer from m-ZrO2 to In2O3, which promotes H2 dissociation and hydrogenation of formate intermediate to methanol (Fig. 6 ). Therefore, the In2O3/m-ZrO2 catalyst exhibits higher activity in the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol than the In2O3/t-ZrO2 catalyst. The Müller group [84] conducted operando-XAS analysis and discovered that the crystal phase of the ZrO2 support determines whether a solid solution with In2O3 is formed. By evaluating the stability and activity of In2O3-based catalysts loaded on different crystal structures, In2O3/m-ZrO2 emerged as a superior catalyst for the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol reaction. Combining In2O3 with m-ZrO2 leads to a good crystalline solid solution, and the active site of the catalyst is an In–VO–Zr site, which includes an oxygen vacancy (VO). In comparison to other materials, t-ZrO2 and a-ZrO2 have an unsatisfactory dispersion of In2O3, resulting in a lack of solid solution structures, and consequently, reduced activity and durability. IR studies conducted by the Müller’s group [85] revealed that the In2O3/m-ZrO2 combination has the greatest capacity for activating H2. By means of in situ XAS, it was demonstrated that the dissociation of H2 take place at the In–O–Zr sites in the solid solution structure. Highly dispersed In sites with valence states between 0–2 do not undergo excessive reduction, leading to improved activity in the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol. Tsoukalou et al. [86] employed in situ DRIFTS and solid-state NMR to recognize formate and methoxy species on In2O3/m-ZrO2, while only formate species were noticed on In2O3/t-ZrO2. In comparison to pure In2O3, the In2O3/m-ZrO2 solid solution structure contains more In–VO–Zr active sites, thus enhancing its capacity to activate hydrogen and hydrogenate formate while preventing the over-reduction of In2O3, resulting in improved catalytic performance. Zhang et al. [87] showed that the strong interactions and reactions between m-ZrO2 and In2O3 activate a batch of In−O bonds at the In2O3/m-ZrO2 interface, thus leading to the formation of oxygen vacancies. Luo et al. [88] developed an efficient and durable CO2 hydrogenation catalyst, In15/m-ZrO2-DTPA, through chelating-assisted impregnation with diethylenetriamine-pentaacetic acid (DTPA). This catalyst improved the reducibility of In2O3 and the presence of interfacial Zr–O–In structures. Benefiting from its unique ability to activate CO2 and carry out hydrogenation, In15/m-ZrO2-DTPA exhibits remarkable catalytic activity for converting CO2 to methanol. It can achieve a selectivity of up to 91% at 533 K and 5.0 MPa and maintain a stable conversion over a period of more than 400 h. In summary, the deposition of In2O3 onto ZrO2 significantly modulated the acidity [80], electronic structure [81], and oxygen vacancy concentration [84] of ZrO2. Through these modifications, In2O3/ZrO2 catalysts demonstrate improved activity and selectivity in the hydrogenation of CO2. Weckhuysen and Monai groups [83] successfully synthesized ZnO/ZrO2 catalysts supported on tetragonal ZrO2 (ZnO/ZrO2-t) and monoclinic ZrO2 (ZnO/ZrO2-m). Compared with ZnO/ZrO2-m, ZnO/ZrO2-t exhibited higher methanol selectivity and methanol yield. They attributed the variation in performance to the redox state and degree of dispersion of Zn. ZnO/ZrO2-t had a high density of ZnO x -ZrO y sites, which favored the formation of active HCOO* species and enhanced the yield and selectivity of methanol along the formate pathway. During the catalytic process, such ZnO clusters were further dispersed on ZrO2-t, while the larger ZnO particles on ZnO/ZrO2-m remained stable throughout the reaction. Furthermore, the authors of this study observed distinct acidity and basicity in ZrO2-m and ZrO2-t through NH3-TPD and CO2-TPD tests. The surface acidity and basicity of ZrO2 can be modulated by loading ZnO onto its surface. Preliminary research suggests that the acidity or basicity of a catalyst’s surface could be linked to its catalytic activity. 3.1.2 Effect of additives To optimize the performance of catalysts, the addition of structural or electronic additives to the catalyst system is often employed, resulting in a notable improvement in catalytic performance. Transition metals and rare earth elements are frequently employed as electronic additives, as their distinct electronic character can augment the catalytic activity of catalysts. The Lobo’s group [89] conducted research on the effects of La and Y additives on In2O3/ZrO2 catalysts for the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol. The use of doping agents impeded the reduction of In2O3 on the surface and created more sites for the adsorption of CO2. The In2O3/ZrO2 catalysts containing La and Y additives displayed a 20% higher methanol selectivity and space-time yield than non-additive catalysts. The Li’s group [51] discovered that the incorporation of Ga into ZnZrO x solid solution catalysts had a positive impact on the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol. The incorporation of Ga into the ZnZrO x solid solution catalyst augmented the adsorption and activation of H2 and CO2, consequently enhancing the catalytic performance of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Lee et al. [90] created a Pd-ZnZrO x solid solution catalyst in which the Pd atoms were atomically dispersed. This catalyst demonstrated a much faster rate of methanol production and a remarkable stability for 100 h, compared to the non-additive ZnZrO x . Incorporating a maximum of 0.8 at% (0.6 wt%) of Pd into the ZnZrO x catalyst can result in an augmented number of oxygen vacancies in the mixed oxide, thus facilitating the production of methanol. Simultaneously, doping Pd lowered the activation barrier of H2 on ZnZrO x , thus facilitating the dissociation of H2. The presence of atomic Pd led to a higher level of heat being released during the dissociation of H2, thus boosting the availability of surface H and facilitating the hydrogenation of CO2 to HCOO* on the adjacent Zn sites, and subsequently, its transformation into methanol. The same group [42] creatively synthesized the Pd/CNT + ZnZrO x catalyst. They first loaded Pd onto CNT using an impregnation method, and then physically mixed it with the ZnZrO x catalyst. As a result, the methanol production rate reached 13.44 mmol gZnZrOx −1 h−1. In previous studies, it was generally believed that there was insufficient activation of H2 during the CO2 hydrogenation process to produce methanol, which limited the catalyst’s activity in methanol generation. However, in their work, CNT played a role as an H2 distributor, effectively delivering Pd-activated H2 to the ZnZrO x surface, thus providing more abundant active H species during the reaction. As a result, the performance of this catalyst was significantly superior to that of the Pd/ZnZrO x catalyst. Furthermore, this catalyst was able to operate continuously for over 600 h, which fully demonstrates its great potential for practical applications. The incorporation of structural or electronic additives has been observed to enhance the activation of H2 and CO2, as well as the adsorption capacity for intermediates, resulting in improved catalytic performance and selectivity. The incorporation of certain alkali metals into the catalyst can facilitate the adsorption and activation of CO2, thus increasing the rate of CO2 conversion. However, due to the more complex system and interactions brought about by the addition of additives, the actual role of additives is still controversial. 3.2 Effect of catalyst synthesis methods The structure and surface characteristics of a catalyst can be altered significantly by employing various catalyst preparation techniques, precursor materials, and pre-treatment procedures such as drying, calcination, and reduction. These modifications will greatly impact the activity, selectivity, toxicity resistance, and stability of the catalytic system. 3.2.1 Effect of catalyst preparation method Traditional techniques for the preparation of catalysts employed in the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol include co-precipitation [36,43], impregnation [48], the sol-gel method [50], flame spray pyrolysis [40], and refluxing ammonia [41]. Recent advances in preparation methods have included microreaction synthesis [38] and EISA [37,44]. Different preparation methods can yield catalysts with distinct structures, thus altering their catalytic performance. Therefore, investigating and optimizing the effect of catalyst preparation techniques on catalytic performance is essential. The Liu’s group [38] studied the effects of mechanical mixing, impregnation, traditional co-precipitation, and microreaction synthesis on the structure and catalytic performance of ZnO/t-ZrO2 mixed oxides. It was evident that the solid solution structure was significantly impacted by the preparation conditions. Impregnation caused alterations to the electronic structure at the Zn/Zr interface; however, this also caused a decrease in the pore structure, resulting in fewer oxygen defects and a decline in catalytic reaction efficiency. By comparison, the solid solution structure augmented the interaction between the Zn/Zr interface, thereby facilitating the formation of more oxygen vacancies and the activation of CO2. The Pérez‐Ramírez group synthesized a range of ZnZrO x solid solution catalysts through the flame spray pyrolysis (FSP) technique [40]. The FSP method-generated catalysts demonstrated a threefold higher methanol yield than catalysts created via co-precipitation. Research revealed that FSP maximized the surface area and formed Zn2+ sites that were atomically dispersed and incorporated into the lattice positions on the surface of ZrO2, which was critical for enhancing catalytic performance. The Li and Wang group achieved a selectivity of 95.2% with a ZnZrO x catalyst prepared by refluxing ammonia, which had a higher concentration of Zn–OH species on its surface [41]. The use of microemulsion methods to form solid solutions results in superior catalytic activity, thermal stability, and regeneration performance due to the uniform solid solution structure and abundant oxygen vacancies [38]. The Wu’s group revealed a range of GaZrO x catalysts developed using the EISA method. The catalysts generated by this method were characterized by an even element distribution and a greater specific surface area, allowing them to exhibit superior catalytic activity under milder conditions compared to those synthesized by co-precipitation [44]. Utilizing the triblock copolymer P123 as a template and n-butanol as a source material, the Li group developed ordered mesoporous ZnO-ZrO2 solid solution catalysts through EISA, exhibiting outstanding catalytic activity [37]. The Liu’s group [91] creatively adopted a plasma-intensified nitrogen-doping technology to prepare a nitrogen-doped indium oxide (N-In2O3) catalyst. It has been confirmed that nitrogen doping is effective in stabilizing In2O3. The doped nitrogen enhances the surface charge localization, which inhibits excessive reduction on the oxide surface and limits the generation of excessive surface oxygen vacancies. Therefore, the method of catalyst preparation can influence the adsorption and desorption of reactants, products, and intermediate species, the availability of catalytic active sites, and other elements that affect catalytic reaction activity by altering the structure of the catalyst. Constructing catalyst structures at a nanoscale is still a challenge, and the regulation of catalyst preparation methods is essential for designing and synthesizing of new catalysts. To gain a deeper understanding of catalyst microstructures at the nanoscale, establish structure-activity relationships, and create high-activity catalysts, advanced catalyst characterization methods, in-situ characterization techniques, and a combination of various characterization methods are required. The Li’s group [43] utilized a high sensitivity low energy ion scattering (LEIS) instrument to analyze the surface elemental ratios of CdZrO x and GaZrO x catalysts. Compared to XPS analysis (2–4 nm for oxide catalysts), the LEIS instrument offers the outermost layer information on catalysts. The Pérez-Ramírez group [80] employed high-pressure chemisorption, which better simulates the adsorption performance of catalysts under reaction conditions. Employing in situ EPR technology, the Wu’s group [44] examined the process of cooperative CO2 activation by oxygen vacancies and Zr3+ ions at the electronic level. Furthermore, through ToF-SIMS characterization methods, they [44] provided initial evidence of the formation of Zr–O–Ga linkages. 3.2.2 Effect of catalyst precursors Currently, metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are being developed as precursors for bimetallic oxide catalysts. The coordination environment of MOFs makes it difficult to effectively incorporate new metal ions, and the addition of secondary metal ions often results in a fragile framework, which makes it difficult to synthesize various bimetallic MOFs using traditional methods [92]. In 2019, Li et al. [45] reported a multifunctional ZrO2 solid solution catalyst (Mx O y −ZrO2, with M = Zn, Co, Cu) for the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol, which was derived from a thermally decomposed Schiff base-modified UiO-66. By altering the metal ions used, the selectivity of C1 hydrogenation products can be easily altered. Analysis conducted by in-situ diffuse reflectance infrared Fourier transform spectroscopy showed that the variation in C1 product selectivity is largely due to the ratio of HCOO*, CH3O*, and CO intermediates on the Zr-based solid solution. The Wang’s group [46] demonstrated the use of a ZrZnO x catalyst, derived from MOF-808, for the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol, as illustrated in Fig. 7 . The catalyst demonstrated an impressive methanol selectivity of over 99%, as well as a space-time yield of up to 190.7 gMeOH kgZn −1 h−1. Results from mechanistic studies indicated that Zn2+ sites are responsible for the activation of H2, and Zn2+–O–Zr4+ sites are critical for the adsorption and transformation of CO2. By designing catalyst precursors, both “bottom-up” and “top-down” preparation methods can be applied to accurately construct the catalyst structure, thereby allowing for the regulation of active sites. Despite the advancements in technology, the distinct electronic properties and interactions between metals still present a great challenge in the practical implementation of experiments. 3.2.3 Effect of catalyst pretreatment conditions To date, there has been limited exploration into the pre-treatment conditions of bimetallic oxide catalysts. The pre-treatment conditions in the preparation of catalysts can be manipulated to alter the structure and electronic properties of the catalyst, thus influencing its catalytic performance. The Witoon’s group [39] explored the impact of calcination temperature (872–1273 K) on ZnO x /ZrO2 and In2O3/ZrO2 catalysts synthesized by the impregnation method. The CO2 adsorption properties of the catalyst surface can be modified by altering the calcination temperature. The highest methanol selectivity (75.1%) at 573 K was achieved by the ZnO x /ZrO2 catalyst calcined at 873 K, which suggests the largest number of weak basic sites at this temperature. The Witoon group also discovered that by altering the calcination temperature of the ZrO2 support, the crystal phase, crystallinity, BET surface area, and CO2 and H2 adsorption-desorption properties of the In2O3/ZrO2 catalyst can be modified, thus enabling the regulation of CH3OH or CH4 production by varying the adsorption strength of reactants on the catalyst surface [93]. The Yan’s group [94] systematically adjusted the drying method, calcination temperature, milling time, and the use of additives. A series of ZnZrO x catalysts with different specific surface areas (4.5–106 m2 g−1), surface oxygen content [O/(Zn + Zr) = 1.60–2.04], and similar surface zinc content [Zn/(Zn + Zr) = ca. 0.20] have been synthesized. The interesting results show that methanol synthesis over ZnZrO x catalysts is structurally sensitive. By calcining the corresponding metal salt precursors, a range of metal oxide catalysts can be obtained, with varying valence states or structures based on the temperature or gas atmosphere used. Therefore, it is essential to analyze the effects of catalyst pre-treatment conditions on its catalytic performance. In this section, we reviewed the factors affecting the catalytic activity of bimetallic oxide catalysts, including crystal phases, additives, and catalyst synthesis methods. Our ultimate goal is to establish benchmarks for industrial application of bimetallic oxide catalysts. We conducted a review of literature and data, but as of now, there are no publicly available benchmarks for industrial application, possibly due to the confidential nature of these data within chemical companies. However, there are some key indicators to refer to regarding Cu-based catalysts: CO2 conversion of 10%–20%, methanol selectivity of ≥ 70%, methanol STY of ≥ 0.5 g gcat −1 h−1, durability of ≥ 1000 h (with < 10% decrease in activity), and exhibiting strong feedstock adaptability (tolerating impurities in industrial-grade CO2, such as H2O and sulfides). Reaction conditions: T = 493−553 K, P = 5–10 MPa, H2/CO2 = 3/1–4/1, GHSV = 4000–10000 h−1. 4 Cost and stability of bimetallic oxide catalyst 4.1 The cost of bimetallic oxide catalyst The pricing of CO2 hydrogenation catalysts varies significantly depending on factors such as catalyst composition, synthesis methods, and purity of raw materials. Based on available data from market sources and industrial references, here’s a rough comparison of the prices of common catalysts used for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol: The Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst is widely used in industrial applications for CO2 hydrogenation due to its affordability and efficiency [95,96]. The cost can vary based on the specific ratios of Cu, ZnO, and Al2O3, as well as the preparation method. The synthesis process of Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst is mature, and the production process does not require very high purity materials, so the production cost is relatively low. Therefore, the price range of Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts is generally ~80 to ~200 $ kg−1 (T@able 2 ). The ZnO-ZrO2 catalyst provides better stability and higher selectivity [36], but due to the market price of Zr is more expensive than Zn, Cu, and Al, and the purity of the raw material requirements are higher, resulting in relatively high production costs. Based on the raw material costs and production expenses, the ZnO-ZrO2 catalyst is likely to be priced at ~130 to ~275 $ kg−1 (T@able 2). This price range can fluctuate based on market dynamics, supplier pricing, production scale, and purity requirements. The GaZrO x catalyst is a high-performance, high-cost catalyst, primarily due to the high prices of its core materials, Ga and Zr, and the stringent purity requirements for these materials, which drive up production costs. Compared to Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts, GaZrO x catalysts offer superior stability and selectivity [44], making them particularly suitable for applications with high catalytic performance demands, such as clean energy conversion and environmental technologies. Despite having a more niche market, the unique properties of GaZrO x catalysts make them crucial in high-end industrial applications. The price range is expected to be around ~230 to ~400 $ kg−1 (T@able 2), with fluctuations driven by raw material costs, production scale, and market dynamics. In the catalytic reaction of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol, the In2O3/ZrO2 catalyst has attracted attention due to its unique properties [48,57]. Although indium is a rare metal, which leads to a higher cost for the In2O3 catalyst, its price typically ranges from ~300 to ~600 $ kg−1 (T@able 2). Compared to traditional Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalysts, the In2O3 catalyst exhibits better stability and durability under high-temperature conditions, allowing it to maintain high catalytic performance over longer periods [48]. Despite the higher price of In2O3/ZrO2 catalysts, particularly due to the strict purity requirements in both raw materials and production processes, their high efficiency and long-term stability make them a worthwhile investment for high-end catalytic applications of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Future research directions include enhancing the Zn content in ZnO-ZrO2 catalysts, reducing the Ga content in GaZrO x catalysts, and decreasing the In content in In2O3/ZrO2 catalysts to align with industrial needs for cost-effective catalysts. Another potential future research direction could involve integrating Cu-based catalysts with bimetallic oxide catalysts to lower catalyst expenses and create catalysts with concurrent low-temperature activity and high stability. 4.2 The stability of bimetallic oxide catalyst Industrial catalysts for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol typically need to operate stably under high temperature (T = 493–573 K for Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst) and pressure conditions (P = 5–10 MPa for Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst) [3]. Catalyst deactivation is usually caused by coke deposition, poisoning, or physical/chemical changes, so regular monitoring and replacement are necessary. To balance cost and benefit, the catalyst replacement cycle is generally 1–2 years, though this can vary depending on the reaction conditions. Catalyst regeneration and performance monitoring can help extend catalyst life, reducing replacement frequency and optimizing economic efficiency. The Cu/ZnO/Al2O3 catalyst is prone to ZnO agglomeration and Cu oxidation under the influence of water in the reaction products, leading to deactivation [2,3]. In contrast, bimetallic oxide catalysts exhibit excellent catalytic stability. The high stability of the ZnO-ZrO2 or GaZrO x catalysts is attributed to the formation of a solid solution structure [36,44], with Zn or Ga species replacing Zr atoms in the ZrO2 lattice. Due to the difference in oxidation states between Zn2+ and Ga3+ ions compared to Zr4+ ions, Zr3+ ions facilitate the stabilization of oxygen vacancies in the formed solid solution structure, leading to the formation of Zr3+–OV structure [44]. The high stability of the In2O3/ZrO2 catalyst arises from strong electronic oxide-support interaction between In species and ZrO2 [81], as well as the resulting solid solution structure [84]. Furthermore, the outstanding thermal stability of ZrO2 allows it to maintain the structural stability of Zn species, Ga species, and In species at high temperatures, effectively preventing phase transitions or sintering of these species under reaction conditions, thereby enhancing the long-term stability and activity of the catalyst. The ZnO-ZrO2 catalyst demonstrated stability exceeding 500 h, maintaining excellent performance under conditions of sulfur-containing compounds (H2S or SO2) and annealing (673 K) [36]. The GaZrO x catalyst demonstrated stability throughout a 100 h durability test, with no observed decline in catalytic performance [44]. The stability of the In2O3/ZrO2 catalyst was well preserved over a 1000 h stability test. Despite the excellent results obtained in stability tests of bimetallic oxide catalysts over 100–1000 h, we believe that real industrial reaction conditions may be more complex than laboratory testing, such as variations in the purity of CO2 sources (containing particulates, sulfides, and nitrides) and fluctuations in reaction temperatures. Therefore, longer durability tests (e.g., 1000–4000 h) and more stringent reaction condition tests (e.g., employing low-purity CO2 as a reactant) will be crucial components of future catalyst activity assessments. 5 Research on catalytic mechanism of bimetallic oxide catalyst 5.1 The study of synergistic effect between two components As compared to single metal oxide catalysts, bimetallic oxide catalysts present more remarkable synergistic effects. The catalyst structure, morphology, and electronic effects all contribute to the synergistic effect, yet the origin of the catalytic activity is still being debated. The Pérez-Ramírez’s group [80] revealed that the m-ZrO2 supported In2O3 catalyst was more active than the t-ZrO2 supported In2O3 catalyst. The authors postulated that the lattice mismatch between In2O3 and m-ZrO2 was the source of catalytic activity, and this mismatch caused an increase in oxygen vacancy concentration in the catalyst, thus augmenting its catalytic activity. The Yu’s group [97,98] used theoretical calculations to investigate the effects of ZrO2 species on the interface of In2O3 and the dissociation of H2. They found that it inhibits the over-formation of oxygen vacancies, but increases the adsorption of CO2 on both intact and defective Zr-In2O3(110) surfaces. The addition of a ZrO2 carrier prevents the dissociation of CO2 and the decomposition of intermediates, thus promoting the hydrogenation of the intermediates to produce methanol. Tsoukalou et al. [84] found that the active site In–VO–Zr of the In2O3/m-ZrO2 catalyst can be sustained by m-ZrO2 lattices that are not overly reduced to In(0), thus preventing deactivation. By contrast, the a-ZrO2 carrier is unable to form solid solutions with In2O3. Therefore, under reaction conditions, In2O3/a-ZrO2 will be rapidly reduced to its metallic form in a matter of minutes. The t-ZrO2 can only partially stabilize the dispersed In2O3 nanocrystals, thus resulting in a lower average oxidation state of the In site of the catalyst below +2. Unfortunately, this also leads to the deactivation of the In2O3/t-ZrO2 due to the over-reduction of In2O3. The Gong’s group [81] determined that the electron transfer from m-ZrO2 to In2O3 increased the electronic density of In2O3, which in turn facilitated the dissociation of H2 and the hydrogenation of formate intermediates to methanol. Zhang et al. [87] found that m-ZrO2 not only enriches CO2 on its surface, but also prevents In2O3 from being reduced to its metallic form. Under reaction conditions, m-ZrO2 acts as a storage for InO x , enabling it to enter and leave the secondary surface layer through the process of InO x surface segregation and redispersion into the m-ZrO2 lattice, as illustrated in Fig. 8 . Despite the numerous experimental studies, the number of reports on the reaction mechanism of ZrO2-based solid solution catalysts is limited. Wang et al. [36] discovered that the 13% ZnO-ZrO2 catalyst prepared by co-precipitation exhibited a catalytic activity that was 6 times higher than that of the mechanically blended ZnO and ZrO2 catalyst [n Zn/(n Zn + n Zr) = 13%], demonstrating a powerful synergistic effect between Zn and Zr in the CO2 hydrogenation reaction. The authors found that the Zn site has an electron modification effect on the adjacent Zr site through a combination of H-D exchange, CO2-TPD, and theoretical calculation results. The synergistic effect enhances H2 activation, as well as the adsorption and hydrogenation of CO2. By combining XPS, ToF-SIMS, EPR, and solid-state NMR, the Wu group [44] examined the GaZrO x catalyst and revealed the synergistic effect between adjacent Ga–O sites and Zr3+–OV sites. The authors speculate that the polarization of Ga–O bonds facilitates the dissociation of H2 into Ga–H and –OH species, and that CO2 is captured by oxygen vacancies and activated by electrons from Zr3+. The specific reaction mechanism is shown in Fig. 9 . 5.2 The study of catalyst’s active sites The catalytic reaction process of hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol involves the adsorption and activation of CO2 and H2, as well as the further hydrogenation transformation of reaction intermediates. The hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol is accomplished by adsorbing and activating CO2 and H2, followed by the hydrogenation of the reaction intermediates. Hence, the study of the active sites has become the theoretical cornerstone for catalyst design. It is generally accepted that the active form of In2O3-based catalysts is partially reduced In2O3−x and the catalytic cycle is facilitated by the generation and annihilation of oxygen vacancies (OV) on In2O3−x [49,56,65,84,98–101]. Tsoukalou et al. [84] employed Operando-XAS to demonstrate that the active site of In2O3/m-ZrO2 catalysts is composed of In–VO–Zr. Through computational and kinetic studies, the Nørskov group [100] revealed that In2O3 catalysts have a high surface reduction degree when exposed to CO2 hydrogenation conditions, resulting in the reduction of the surface layers to metallic In. The activity of the In2O3 surface is dependent on the number of reduced In layers. The Gao group [101] demonstrated through density functional theory calculations that the indium atoms near the oxygen vacancy (VO) sites (VO3 and VO4) on the In2O3(110) surface and the indium atoms at the VO3 site on the In2O3(111) surface possess stronger Lewis acidity and also have higher oxygen vacancy formation energies, which makes them more favorable for the adsorption of H2 and CO2. It was established by Wang et al. [36] that Zn species sites are the source of hydrogen activation, providing active hydrogen to catalyze the hydrogenation of surface carbonate species. Additionally, Zr sites were found to capture CO2 molecules, and hydrogenation of CO2 can occur at the interface between Zn and Zr species. The Wu’s group [44] identified the Zr3+–OV–Ga–O structure as the active site of the catalyst, enabling the adsorption of CO2, the dissociation of H2, and the subsequent hydrogenation transformation of intermediates. Tada et al. [102] explored the effect of zinc content on the Zn x Zr1−x O2−x catalyst for the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol and determined the active site structure through calculations and experiments. It is speculated that Zn–O–Zr sites are the active sites of the Zn x Zr1−x O2−x catalyst, with Zn species being responsible for H2 activation and Zr species for CO2 activation. Intermediate species such as formate and methoxy species are formed on Zr species. The Li’s group [103] demonstrated that the asymmetric Zn−O−Zr structure within the ZnZrO x solid solution catalyst serves as the active site, as confirmed by in situ experiments. Specifically, the Zn site activates H2, the Zr site aids in stabilizing reaction intermediates, and the bidentate carbonate resulting from CO2 adsorption undergoes hydrogenation to form formate on the Zn−O−Zr sites. The ZnZrO x catalyst, characterized by a moderate density of Zn−O−Zr sites, was found by the same group [104] to be more effective in activating H2 and CO2, with a lower energy barrier for the rate-determining step, thus demonstrating superior catalytic activity. The inverse Zr−ZnO catalyst synthesized by Wang et al. [105] promotes electron transfer from Zr to Zn, thereby accelerating hydrogen dissociation to yield more hydride species. Additionally, this electronic interaction enhances the adsorption of CO2, leading to the formation of bidentate bicarbonate and carbonate species that are hydrogenated into formate and methoxy species. The structure of active sites of bimetallic oxide catalysts is determined by the properties of metals and the composition of the catalyst. Therefore, to gain a better understanding of the catalytic active sites, a range of characterization methods must be employed to analyze their specific connectivity and electron transfer modes. Currently, no universal framework has been established that can summarize and generalize the study of active sites. 5.3 The study of catalytic reaction pathways Generally, there are two primary routes for the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol (Fig. 10 ). The formate pathway begins with the reaction of CO2 and pre-adsorbed surface atoms of hydrogen via the Eley-Rideal or Langmuir-Hinshelwood mechanism to produce formate (HCOO*). Subsequently, formate species are hydrogenated to yield dioxomethylene (H2COO*), formaldehyde (H2CO*), methoxy (CH3O*), and methanol (CH3OH). The RWGS + CO-hydrogenation pathway [106] involves the conversion of CO2 to CO via a carboxyl (COOH*) intermediate or direct dissociation, followed by the hydrogenation of CO to form methanol through formyl (HCO*), formaldehyde (H2CO*), and methoxy (CH3O*) intermediates. The key step in CO2 hydrogenation is to break a single C=O bond, rather than two. The conversion process can be easily carried out on the surface of defective metal oxides, as an oxygen atom of CO2 or its hydrogenated intermediate will replenish the surface oxygen vacancy. Additionally, other catalytic mechanisms have been proposed [3]. The complexity of the reaction mechanism for bimetallic oxide catalysts, caused by the varied coordination of carbonate and formate species on the catalyst surface, necessitates a combined experimental and theoretical approach for further study. The Ge and Liu groups [56,99] used DFT calculations to determine that the most efficient route for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol on the In2O3 (110) surface is the formate pathway, which follows the sequence of CO2 → HCOO* → H2CO* → H3CO* → CH3OH, as illustrated in Fig. 11 . The Yu’s group conducted DFT calculations to investigate the mechanism of CO2 and CO hydrogenation to methanol on the defective ZrO2-supported In2O3 (110) surface. The results of the study revealed that the reaction pathway of In2O3/ZrO2 catalysts is CO2 → HCOO* → polydentate H2CO* (p-H2CO*) → monodentate H2CO* (mono-H2CO*) → H3CO* → CH3OH [97,98]. The CO2 hydrogenation to methanol on ZnO-ZrO2 solid solution catalysts follows the formate pathway as well. The Li’s group [36] identified HCOO* and H3CO* species during the reaction process by utilizing in-situ DRIFTS. Subsequently, DFT calculations were conducted to evaluate the reaction pathways of formate and RWGS + CO-hydrogenation. The findings revealed that the CO2 hydrogenation to methanol on ZnO-ZrO2 surface proceeds through the formate pathway. By utilizing solid-state NMR and a surface species separation strategy, the Wu group established that formate was the essential intermediate on the GaZrO x catalyst surface [44]. The Li’s group [107] discovered that the synthesis of methanol was mainly carried out through the formate pathway on a Zn/ZrO2 solid solution catalyst, which involves the tridentate HCOO* intermediate. This pathway proceeds from CO2 to CO3*, then to tridentate HCOO*, followed by bidentate HCO*, bidentate H2CO*, monodentate H2CO*, H3CO*, and finally CH3OH. The rate-determining step in this process is the conversion of bidentate H2CO* to monodentate H2CO*. The key intermediates and reaction pathways vary depending on the strength of the bond between the catalyst and the intermediates, as well as the energy barriers that must be overcome for further conversion. Some crucial intermediates cannot be directly observed experimentally; therefore, optimizing theoretical calculations and designing experimental characterizations are still essential tasks in order to understand the catalytic reaction pathways. 5.4 The study of kinetic processes At temperatures ranging from 473 to 633 K and pressures of 2 to 5 MPa, with a hydrogen to CO2 ratio of 3/1 or 4/1, the thermodynamic equilibrium of bimetallic oxide-catalyzed CO2 hydrogenation to methanol favors the endothermic RWGS reaction over the exothermic MS reaction. Therefore, to achieve a high selectivity for methanol, the reaction must be conducted under kinetic control. Cu-based catalysts are extensively used in industrial processes for the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol, and numerous kinetic models have been developed to optimize production and design of advanced reactors [71,108]. Although there is no consensus on which kinetic model is preferable for industrial production, they all offer practical guidance [71]. Investigations into the kinetic properties of bimetallic oxide catalysts for the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol mainly focus on ZnO-ZrO2 and In2O3-based catalysts. The Li’s group [109] investigated the reaction kinetics of CO2 hydrogenation on ZnZrO x catalysts. The findings suggest that the reaction orders of H2 and CO2 are approximately 0.5 and 0, respectively, indicating an insufficiency of activated H* on the catalysts. The Li group [109] proposes that the migration of H* on the catalysts is the rate-determining step for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Following this the same group reported that ZnZrO x -RA exhibits a reduced activation energy for methanol synthesis, a higher reaction order in H2, and a comparable reaction order in CO2 compared to ZnZrO x -CP [41]. The López and Pérez-Ramírez groups established essential kinetic data of CO2 hydrogenation to methanol on In2O3 by utilizing the Arrhenius activation energy and reaction order diagrams [110]. The experimental results revealed that the apparent activation energy for MS was lower than that of RWGS, which explains why In2O3 has such an outstanding methanol selectivity. An increase in CO2 concentration caused a slight decrease in the rate of methanol production, while an increase in H2 content resulted in a considerable enhancement in the rate of methanol production, CO2 conversion rate, and methanol selectivity. The reaction rate was slightly inhibited by methanol, while water exerted a considerable inhibitory effect [110]. The Han’s group conducted a study to investigate the influence of supports on the kinetics of CO2 hydrogenation over In2O3-based catalysts. Through steady-state kinetics, high-pressure in situ diffuse reflectance infrared spectroscopy and temperature-programmed experiments, it was demonstrated that formate and methoxy were the key surface reaction intermediates on In2O3/ZrO2, while methanol was mainly produced via stepwise hydrogenation of surface formate [111]. The Creaser’s group [112] proposed a single-site kinetic model based on the Langmuir-Hinshelwood-Hougen-Watson (LHHW) mechanism for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol over In2O3 and compared it with a dual-site model. The single-site model was more accurate in predicting experimental results, thus providing a solid foundation for the development of reactors and processes. The Bhattacharya’s group [113] conducted kinetic investigations on In2O3/CeO2 catalysts and developed a dual-site model based on the LHHW mechanism. The simulation results suggested that the activation energy for methanol synthesis on In2O3/CeO2 was lower, thus indicating that it could be a more efficient catalyst for CO2 hydrogenation to methanol. Through kinetic studies, a more comprehensive understanding of catalytic reactions can be gained, allowing for the identification of factors that are essential or non-essential to the reaction, and enabling the precise optimization of reaction conditions for improved performance. Despite the gap between theory and practice, mathematical equations for kinetic analysis need further refinement to more accurately simulate actual conditions. 6 Conclusions and prospects 6.1 Conclusions In response to the growing global warming and energy crisis, researchers have devoted considerable effort to developing effective catalysts for the hydrogenation of CO2 to methanol. Novel bimetallic oxide catalysts, including ZrO2-based solid solution catalysts and In2O3-based oxide catalysts, have been identified as possessing high methanol selectivity and catalytic activity, as well as excellent stability. These catalysts are expected to represent the next generation of industrial-scale CO2 hydrogenation to methanol catalysts. In order to further synthesize highly active catalysts, a deeper understanding of the structure of active sites and reaction mechanisms of catalysts is the first crucial aspect. Previous studies have indicated that the surface structure of bimetallic oxide catalysts undergoes intriguing dynamic surface restructuring during reactions. Future studies should integrate advanced synthesis techniques with operando methods like EPR, XAS, AP-XPS, etc., to clarify the development of active sites at both electronic and atomic levels. In terms of the reaction mechanism, it is widely acknowledged that oxygen vacancies on the catalyst surface act as sites for the adsorption and activation of CO2. H2 activation takes place on Zn–O, In–O, and Ga–O bonds, resulting in the production of active H* species. The currently accepted viewpoint is that surface formate species (HCOO*) and surface methoxy species (CH3O*) are key reaction intermediates in the formation of methanol. Subsequent investigations should aim to explain the generation mechanisms of surface formate species. Another crucial aspect to consider is how to enhance the selectivity of methanol. The selectivity of methanol via CO2 hydrogenation is jointly determined by the intrinsic properties of the catalyst (such as the strength of oxygen vacancies for CO2 adsorption, surface acidity/basicity, interactions between two metal elements, and CO adsorption strength) and external conditions (including temperature, pressure, and H2/CO2 ratio). By synergistically designing catalyst compositions, engineering defects, and optimizing reaction conditions, the hydrogenation efficiency of the surface formate pathway can be selectively enhanced while suppressing side reaction pathways. 6.2 Prospects Although bimetallic oxide catalysts have made significant strides in catalyzing the production of methanol through CO2 hydrogenation, there are still shortcomings in current research, such as the low-temperature activity of bimetallic oxide catalysts is insufficient, the systems of bimetallic oxides are limited, and there is a lack of theoretical research on ZrO2-based solid solution catalysts. These issues significantly impede the development of bimetallic oxide catalyst systems in the field of methanol production via CO2 hydrogenation, necessitating prompt resolution of the aforementioned challenges. Based on these, we have put forward some personal perspectives. (1) Enhancing the performance of existing bimetallic oxide catalysts is a key priority. Research has shown that selecting appropriate catalyst synthesis methods, catalytic additives, precursors, and pre-treatment conditions is crucial for controlling the composition and surface morphology of the catalysts, potentially leading to enhanced activity and selectivity. However, producing single-crystal phase ZrO2-based bimetallic oxide catalysts remains a challenge, and further work is needed to develop catalysts with well-defined structures. Additionally, the impact of varying crystal structures of In2O3 in In2O3-based catalysts warrants further investigation. (2) The creation of novel catalytic systems is an ongoing challenge. While research on bimetallic oxide catalysts has focused primarily on ZrO2-based solid solution catalysts and In2O3-based oxide catalysts, relatively little attention has been given to the development of entirely new catalytic systems. Exploring the potential of combining different metal elements to create new catalytic systems is a key challenge moving forward. (3) Extensive theoretical investigation into bimetallic synergies, active site structures, catalytic reaction pathways, and kinetic processes is essential. Although considerable research has focused on In2O3-based catalysts, relatively few theoretical studies have been conducted on ZrO2-based solid solution catalysts. The catalytic kinetic processes and models are not yet fully understood, making the development of new models crucial for industrial production and reactor design. Jian-Feng Wu , PhD, is an Associate Research Fellow at the State Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Catalysis and Carbon Dioxide Utilization, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. He obtained his B.A. degree in 2008 and Ph.D. degree in 2014 from Lanzhou University, China. Following this, he conducted postdoctoral research at the Center for Environmentally Beneficial Catalysis at the University of Kansas, USA, from 2014 to 2017. Wu has held positions at the School of Chemistry and Chemical Engineering, Lanzhou University (2017–2023), and currently at the State Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Catalysis and Carbon Dioxide Utilization, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences (since 2023). He was recognized as a beneficiary of the key talent program in Gansu Province in 2024 and the talent introduction program of the Chinese Academy of Sciences in 2025. His research primarily focuses on low carbon catalysis, encompassing CO2 hydrogenation to methanol and methane conversion to CH3OH, CH3COOH, and HCOOH. Lingjun Chou , PhD, Professor in the State Key Laboratory of Low Carbon Catalysis and Carbon Dioxide Utilization, Lanzhou Institute of Chemical Physics, Chinese Academy of Sciences. Research major field is on catalytic material and catalytic processes related to energy conversion.

coredata.dc:description: Against the backdrop of global energy and environmental crises, the technology of CO2 hydrogenation to produce methanol is garnering widespread attention as an innovative carbon capture and utilization solution. Bimetallic oxide catalysts have emerged as the most promising research subject in the field due to their exceptional catalytic performance and stability. The performance of bimetallic oxide catalysts is influenced by multiple factors, including the selection of carrier materials, the addition of promoters, and the synthesis process. Different types of bimetallic oxide catalysts exhibit significant differences in microstructure, surface active sites, and electronic structure, which directly determine the yield and selectivity of methanol. Although bimetallic oxide catalysts offer significant advantages over traditional copper-based catalysts, they still encounter challenges related to activity and cost. In order to enhance catalyst performance, future investigations must delve into microstructure control, surface modification, and reaction kinetics.
